results.title: head_phone_film_poems
results.brief_description:
head_phone_film_poems is a collection of thirteen films that creatively remix material from online archives including the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) film material in the National Archives of Australia, crime scene photographs from the Justice and Police Museum Sydney, and Gibson’s own social-media-stored collection of strange late-night phenomena filmed in his neighbourhood over the past decade. Drawing on these caches of ‘readymade’ footage, the head_phone_film_poems are shaped by three guiding principles: they must be produced entirely on the iPhone, they must feature some visualised language and they must suggest an enormous amount more than they show.

[Sourced from ACMI website event page https://www.acmi.net.au/whats-on/ross-gibson-head_phone_film_poems/ 9/6/2021]

Drawing on these caches of ‘readymade’ footage, the head_phone_film_poems are shaped by three guiding principles: they must be produced entirely on the iPhone, they must feature some visualised language and they must suggest an enormous amount more than they show.

results.title: Spotlights: Bruna Papandrea
results.brief_description: Eric Banadinović AM, known professionally as Eric Bana, is an Australian actor. He began his career in the sketch comedy series Full Frontal (1993–97) before gaining notice in the comedy/drama The Castle (1997) before gaining critical acclaim as the lead in Chopper (2000).
results.description: Bruna Papandrea is an Australian film and television producer and the founder of production company Made Up Stories, which is set to release the upcoming adaptation of Liane Moriarty’s Nine Perfect Strangers. Prior to Made Up Stories, Papandrea co-founded the production company, Pacific Standard, with Reese Witherspoon, which produced Gone Girl and Big Little Lies.
description_for_label: Bruna Papandrea is an Australian film and television producer and the founder of production company Made Up Stories, which is set to release the upcoming adaptation of Liane Moriarty’s Nine Perfect Strangers. Prior to Made Up Stories, Papandrea co-founded the production company, Pacific Standard, with Reese Witherspoon, which produced Gone Girl and Big Little Lies.

results.title: A Good Eye for Story
results.credit_line:
Filmed in Mbantua (Alice Springs)
Equipment provided by Panavision Australia
Colour by Matt Fezz
Special thanks to CAAMA Productions
results.material_description: HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 3:06 min
results.brief_description: Dylan River’s film A Good Eye for Story is a quirky and intimate picture looking at the framework for which he shares his ideas and the impact that his family, community and the landscape around Alice Springs have had on his growing practice as a storyteller.
results.headline_credit_for_label:
filmed in Mbantua (Alice Springs)

Equipment provided by Panavision Australia

Colour by Matt Fezz
results.description:
Dylan River is a filmmaker who shares stories from his unique perspective as a Kaytetye man. River works across many roles including cinematography, directing, and writing, for web series, documentary, short film, and cinema.

River’s film A Good Eye for Story is a quirky and intimate picture looking at the framework for which he shares his ideas and the impact that his family, community and the landscape around Alice Springs have had on his growing practice as a storyteller.

“This film explores my journey over the past ten years of being behind the cinema camera. The way my eye has changed from looking at images as being formulaic to appreciating the story behind every one.” – Dylan River
description_for_label:
Dylan River is a filmmaker who shares stories from his unique perspective as a Kaytetye man. River works across many roles including cinematography, directing, and writing, for web series, documentary, short film, and cinema.

“This film explores my journey over the past ten years of being behind the cinema camera. The way my eye has changed from looking at images as being formulaic to appreciating the story behind every one.” – Dylan River

results.title: The Silenced
results.material_description: HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 6:18 min
results.brief_description: In works such as The Silenced, Trawlwoolway artist Julie Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories, interrogating colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.description:
Julie Gough is a Trawlwoolway artist, writer and curator who lives in Hobart, Tasmania. Gough works across many mediums including video, sound and installation. Her work interrogates colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples. In works such as The Silenced Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories. These works are often deeply personal, referring to her own and her family’s experiences as Tasmanian Aboriginal people.

“At least 185 Aboriginal children in Lutruwita / Van Diemen’s Land / Tasmania lived with colonists before the 1850s. The Silenced is an introduction to the task of finding these children within slim records. Reinstating them back on the Country they lived, isolated from their dead and exiled kin, amongst the colonists responsible, clearly reveals the genocidal intent of Empire.” – Julie Gough
description_for_label:
Julie Gough is a Trawlwoolway artist, writer and curator who lives in Hobart, Tasmania. Gough works across many mediums including video, sound and installation. Her work interrogates colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples. In works such as The Silenced Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories. These works are often deeply personal, referring to her own and her family’s experiences as Tasmanian Aboriginal people.

“At least 185 Aboriginal children in Lutruwita / Van Diemen’s Land / Tasmania lived with colonists before the 1850s. The Silenced is an introduction to the task of finding these children within slim records. Reinstating them back on the Country they lived, isolated from their dead and exiled kin, amongst the colonists responsible, clearly reveals the genocidal intent of Empire.” – Julie Gough

results.title: Where the Desert Meets the Sea
results.credit_line:
Cinematography by Brad Gibb 
Edited by Ben Lane  
Special thanks to Wayne Miller
results.material_description: HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 4:12 min
results.brief_description: Shelley Ware’s film Where the Desert Meets the Sea (2020) tells the story of her family’s legacy that has led her to a career in AFL presenting.
results.description:
Shelley Ware is one of Australia’s most respected female sports presenters. She is a Yankunytjatjara, Wirangu and Kokatha woman, well known for her role on the SBS program Marngrook Footy Show. Currently, Ware hosts the AFL.com web show ‘Colour of Your Jumper.’ Ware is also an educator, and her film Where the Desert Meets the Sea tells the story of her family’s legacy that has led her to a career in AFL presenting.

“This is a story of my Country and why the game of AFL and the Koonibba Football Club are so important to me. I share the stories of my people, as a teacher and sports presenter, so that our children, can be what they see.” – Shelley Ware
description_for_label:
Shelley Ware is one of Australia’s most respected female sports presenters. She is a Yankunytjatjara, Wirangu and Kokatha woman, well known for her role on the SBS program Marngrook Footy Show. “This is a story of my Country and why the game of AFL and the Koonibba Football Club are so important to me. I share the stories of my people, as a teacher and sports presenter, so that our children, can be what they see.” – Shelley Ware

results.title: Jaara Nyilamum
results.creator_credit: Lou Bennett AM and Romaine Moreton
results.brief_description:
2021, Romaine Moreton (Goenpul Yagerabul Minjungbal Bundjalung), Lou Bennett AM (Dja Dja Warrung, Yorta Yorta)
Filmed & Edited by Romaine Moreton, Co-Directed by Romaine Moreton & Lou Bennett AM
H264 projection,16:9, colour, 7:39 mins
Jaara Nyilamum (song composition) Performed by Dr Lou Bennett AM and the Australian String Quartet, Composed by Dr Lou Bennett AM, Arranged by Iain Grandage, Produced by Stephen Snelleman

Dr Lou Bennett is a Performer, Songwriter, Musical and Artistic Director, Composer, Actor, Soundscape Designer and Academic. Lou’s research project ‘Sovereign Language Rematriation Through Song Pedagogy’ focusses on the importance and relevance of Indigenous language retrieval, reclamation, and regeneration through the medium of the Arts to enhance community health and wellbeing. Dr Romaine Moreton is an artist, writer, performer, filmmaker, and her proposes an Indigenous philosophy of story-telling and embodied knowledge, with her work constantly drawing our attention back to the importance of the breath in Indigenous cultural practices.

The making of Jaara Nyilamum (2021) evoked a stillness that restored us to full sensual immersion within country, and from this place of rooted calmness, country reaffirmed our Law is real. Jaara Nyilamum became most profound when we realised this was more than a film about ceremony, but was in fact, ceremony itself. Our challenge was to create a production model that aligned with our beliefs and centralised our Law, pushed back against monochronic time and engaged with the deep cycles of place, where we embraced Belonging as a process of constant renewal and Rematration.

results.title: Yanmeeyarr
results.credit_line:
Vicki Couzens

Acrylic paint, carved and hand-polished acrylic lens

Laser cut mirror finish and etched stainless steel

Commissioned by ACMI and co-created with Jeph Neale and Hilary Jackman
results.material_description:
Acrylic paint, carved and hand-polished acrylic lens.
Laser cut mirror finish and etched stainless steel.
results.brief_description: In Yanmeeyarr, Gunditjmara artist Vicki Couzens references how ochre markings on the body capture and reflect light during ceremony, creating a centuries-spanning connection between traditional First Peoples storytelling and the contemporary moving image.

constellations_primary.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_primary.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.description:
Light and shadow have been a powerful storytelling tool long before they were the basis for the moving image. For thousands of generations in Australia, First Peoples storytelling has harnessed the movement of the world and play of light: the special glow of sunset to catch the movement of dancing feet, the flickering campfire as tales are told in the night, the story of stars and constellations told in the Dreaming.

In this multi-part artwork Gunditjmara artist Vicki Couzens references how ochre markings on the body capture and reflect light during ceremony, creating a centuries-spanning connection between traditional First Peoples storytelling and the contemporary moving image.

“Where does moving image originate? Shadow and light, elemental movement and action; see figures in formation, ceremony in the circle, moving, in rhythm, in rhyme with the heartbeat, sunlight, moon shadow, Yanmeeyarr… flickering in firelight. Dancers painted and adorned, in corroboree, in ceremony, telling story through the dance. The viewer in movement and reflection becomes part of the dance, as the figures become animated. Yanmeeyarr, flickering in the firelight, is reflected in the present; the viewer and the new technologies of today, become part of the work and the ongoing past-present-future of our storytelling continuum.” – Vicki Couzens

Yanmeeyarr is generously supported by the Sidney Myer Fund
description_for_label:

For thousands of generations in Australia, First Peoples storytelling has harnessed the movement of the world and play of light: the special glow of sunset to catch the movement of dancing feet, the flickering campfire as tales are told in the night, the story of stars and constellations told in the Dreaming.

In this multi-part artwork Gunditjmara artist Vicki Couzens references how ochre markings on the body capture and reflect light during ceremony, creating a centuries-spanning connection between traditional First Peoples storytelling and the contemporary moving image.

“Where does moving image originate? Shadow and light, elemental movement and action; see figures in formation, ceremony in the circle, moving, in rhythm, in rhyme with the heartbeat, sunlight, moon shadow, Yanmeeyarr… flickering in firelight. Dancers painted and adorned, in corroboree, in ceremony, telling story through the dance. The viewer in movement and reflection becomes part of the dance, as the figures become animated. Yanmeeyarr, flickering in the firelight, is reflected in the present; the viewer and the new technologies of today, become part of the work and the ongoing past-present-future of our storytelling continuum.” – Vicki Couzens

Yanmeeyarr is generously supported by the Sidney Myer Fund

results.title: You will see me
results.creator_credit: Conor Bateman, Field Carr and Sari Braithwaite
results.brief_description: You will see me explores the way artists and amateurs alike have turned the camera on themselves since they became more accessible in the mid-20th century, and how this tradition is continued, amplified and tranformed through reality TV, the internet and social media.

constellations_primary.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_primary.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

results.description: The camera doesn’t just capture us, it frames who we are and how we’re seen. Since the camera became more accessible in the mid-20th century, artists and amateurs alike have turned the lens on themselves to create a stage both private and public. This tradition is continued, amplified and transformed through reality TV, the internet and social media, the latest forms to use straight-to-camera techniques to share our common humanity, project authenticity and illuminate how a sense of self can be constructed through the moving image.
description_for_label: The camera doesn’t just capture us, it frames who we are and how we’re seen. Since the camera became more accessible in the mid-20th century, artists and amateurs alike have turned the lens on themselves to create a stage both private and public. This tradition is continued, amplified and transformed through reality TV, the internet and social media, the latest forms to use straight-to-camera techniques to share our common humanity, project authenticity and illuminate how a sense of self can be constructed through the moving image.

results.title: Spotlights: Eric Bana
results.brief_description: Eric Banadinović AM, known professionally as Eric Bana, is an Australian actor. He began his career in the sketch comedy series Full Frontal (1993–97) before gaining notice in the comedy/drama The Castle (1997) before gaining critical acclaim as the lead in Chopper (2000).

constellations_primary.name: Eric Bana
constellations_primary.description: There must be something that draws Australian creatives like Eric Bana to darker material as they shoot to stardom overseas. Australia's penal colony past perhaps?

results.description: Eric Bana is an Australian actor who began his career in the sketch comedy series Full Frontal (1993–97) before gaining notice in the comedy/drama The Castle (1997). Soon after he gained critical recognition in the biographical crime film Chopper (2000). Eric discusses the influence of the car on the Australian psyche.
description_for_label: Eric Bana is an Australian actor who began his career in the sketch comedy series Full Frontal (1993–97) before gaining notice in the comedy/drama The Castle (1997). Soon after he gained critical recognition in the biographical crime film Chopper (2000). Eric discusses the influence of the car on the Australian psyche.
